supporting_text: This action plan recognises that AMR is a 'one health' problem, and highlights the need for an effective 'one health' approach.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including improving awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance through effective communication, education, and training.
The NAP includes strategies for animal health, such as training and professional education on AMR in the veterinary sector.
The NAP addresses environmental health, including the need for surveillance of antimicrobial resistance and consumption of antibiotics as it relates to environmental health.
The NAP includes strategies related to agricultural practices and the use of antimicrobials in food production.
The NAP will be accompanied by a national AMR progress report regarding its implementation.
The NAP outlines specific interventions and activities with proposed deadlines.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The budget for AMR activities will originate from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Agriculture, and other relevant government and private sectors.
The NAP mentions the need for a realistic AMR activity and initiatives budget after assessing investment needs, funding sources, and relevant partners to engage.
In January 2017, a national, multi-sectoral working group was created to develop the action plan for antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP indicates the need for legislation and regulations which govern importation, marketing authorisation/sales, and access to antibiotics for human use.
The NAP includes plans to include antimicrobial resistance in undergraduate curricula for medical doctors, veterinarians, and nurses.
The NAP outlines plans to conduct regular nationwide awareness campaigns on AMR.
The NAP mentions the need for international technical collaboration and information sharing on all aspects of antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP emphasizes the need for a national surveillance system for antimicrobial resistance and the collection of AMR data.
The NAP includes plans to strengthen AMR data collection across all sectors.
The NAP includes objectives to reduce the incidence of infection through effective sanitation, hygiene, and infection prevention measures.
The NAP aligns itself to intergovernmental standards where relevant, including the OIE Code.
The NAP mentions the need for an institutional essentials medicines list at the government hospital.
The NAP indicates the need for binding rules and restrictions on the use of antimicrobials.
The NAP includes plans to participate in regional and international collaborative research to support the development of new medicines, diagnostic tools, and vaccines.
